content.data: Import DXF
image253.png
Import DXF Parts allows you to bring in Parts you have created in other CAD packages into the S2M CENTER.
image254.png
To Import a DXF Part:

Click the Select   button. 
 
 
 Browse to the location of your DXF Part, click on it, and click Open. See the  Other CAD Importers  topic for other import options.
Click the Select   button.
Click the Select   button.
image255.png
Browse to the location of your DXF Part, click on it, and click Open. See the  Other CAD Importers  topic for other import options.
Browse to the location of your DXF Part, click on it, and click Open. See the  Other CAD Importers  topic for other import options.
You can use standard Windows Ctrl + Click or Shift + Click combinations to select multiple DXF's here.
Information.png
image256.png
Click the Open button.
Click the Open button.
Click the Open button.

Once your DXF Parts are displayed on the screen they ready to be added to your Job by clicking Save. However, there are several options prior to Adding the Part to the Job you may want to modify. First, your Parts will appear on the Viewing Screen to the Left.
image257.png

By selecting each Layer Name in the list at the upper Right of the screen you can see that Operation highlight in the preview screen you will also be able to see below how the S2M CENTER has translated the Layer Names.

Each identified Part or set of Operations will be displayed, when selected, either in Blue or in Red. If the Part or Operation is displayed in Red it means the S2M CENTER has been unable to determine the Operation Type. This typically means that the Layer has not been defined correctly. You can either edit the Layer Scheme for the S2M CENTER or edit the Layer Name within the DXF from this area.
Information.png
Edit DXF Layer Scheme
image951.gif
This is where you define how your Layers coming from your CAD package are defined.
image462.png
Toolbar
image463.png
There are 5 options in the toolbar:
Layer Scheme Selector -  Allows you to select which DXF Layer Scheme to use.
image464.png
New Scheme -  Allows you to create a new DXF Layer Scheme.
image465.png
Copy Scheme -  Allows you to copy the current DXF Layer Scheme.
image466.png
Rename Scheme -  Allows you to rename the current DXF layer Scheme.
image467.png
Delete Scheme -  Allows you to delete the current DXF Layer Scheme.
image468.png
There are three sections in the Advanced Screen:
Layers  - There are 12 options in the Layers Section.

Part - Specifies which Layer defines the Parts boundary. 
 
 
 Outline - Specifies which Layer defines the Parts Outline. 
 
 
 Vertical Bore - Specifies which Layer defines Vertical Boring Operations. 
 
 
 Horizontal Bore - Specifies which Layer defines Horizontal Boring Operations. 
 
 
 Left Horizontal Bore- Specifies which Layer defines Left Horizontal Boring Operations. 
 
 
 Right Horizontal Bore- Specifies which Layer defines Right Horizontal Boring Operations. 
 
 
 Front Horizontal Bore- Specifies which Layer defines Front Horizontal Boring Operations. 
 
 
 Back Horizontal Bore- Specifies which Layer defines Back Horizontal Boring Operations. 
 
 
 Route - Specifies which Layer defines Route Operations. 
 
 
 Dado - Specifies which Layer defines Dado Operations. 
 
 
 Pocket - Specifies which Layer defines Pocket Operations. 
 
 
 Edge Miter - Specifies which Layer defines an Edge Miter.
Part - Specifies which Layer defines the Parts boundary.
Part - Specifies which Layer defines the Parts boundary.
Outline - Specifies which Layer defines the Parts Outline.
Outline - Specifies which Layer defines the Parts Outline.
Vertical Bore - Specifies which Layer defines Vertical Boring Operations.
Vertical Bore - Specifies which Layer defines Vertical Boring Operations.
Horizontal Bore - Specifies which Layer defines Horizontal Boring Operations.
Horizontal Bore - Specifies which Layer defines Horizontal Boring Operations.
Left Horizontal Bore- Specifies which Layer defines Left Horizontal Boring Operations.
Left Horizontal Bore- Specifies which Layer defines Left Horizontal Boring Operations.
Right Horizontal Bore- Specifies which Layer defines Right Horizontal Boring Operations.
Right Horizontal Bore- Specifies which Layer defines Right Horizontal Boring Operations.
Front Horizontal Bore- Specifies which Layer defines Front Horizontal Boring Operations.
Front Horizontal Bore- Specifies which Layer defines Front Horizontal Boring Operations.
Back Horizontal Bore- Specifies which Layer defines Back Horizontal Boring Operations.
Back Horizontal Bore- Specifies which Layer defines Back Horizontal Boring Operations.
Route - Specifies which Layer defines Route Operations.
Route - Specifies which Layer defines Route Operations.
Dado - Specifies which Layer defines Dado Operations.
Dado - Specifies which Layer defines Dado Operations.
Pocket - Specifies which Layer defines Pocket Operations.
Pocket - Specifies which Layer defines Pocket Operations.
Edge Miter - Specifies which Layer defines an Edge Miter.
Edge Miter - Specifies which Layer defines an Edge Miter.
Keywords  - There are 8 options in the Keywords Section.

Tool Number - Specify the character that represents your Tool Number. Typically it is the letter T. 
 
 
 Operation Depth - Specify the character that represents your Operation Depth. Typically it is the letter D. 
 
 
 Operation Width - Specify the character that represents your Operation Width. Typically it is the letter W. 
 
 
 Offset Left - Specify the character that represents if your Operation needs to machine with a Left Cutter Offset (Comp). Typically it is the letter L. 
 
 
 Offset Right - Specify the character that represents if your Operation needs to machine with a Right Cutter Offset (Comp). Typically it is the letter R. 
 
 
 Tool Inside - Specify the character that represents if your Operation needs to be machined on the Inside. 
 
 
 Tool Outside - Specify the character that represents if your Operation needs to be machined on the Outside. 
 
 
 Secondary Face - Identifies that the Operation is on the Secondary Face. Without this designation on an operation the assumption is the Operation is on the Primary Face. This allows you to define machining on both faces of the Part from one DXF drawing.

Operation Depth - Specify the character that represents your Operation Depth. Typically it is the letter D.

Operation Width - Specify the character that represents your Operation Width. Typically it is the letter W.

Offset Left - Specify the character that represents if your Operation needs to machine with a Left Cutter Offset (Comp). Typically it is the letter L.
Offset Left - Specify the character that represents if your Operation needs to machine with a Left Cutter Offset (Comp). Typically it is the letter L.
Offset Right - Specify the character that represents if your Operation needs to machine with a Right Cutter Offset (Comp). Typically it is the letter R.
Offset Right - Specify the character that represents if your Operation needs to machine with a Right Cutter Offset (Comp). Typically it is the letter R.
Tool Inside - Specify the character that represents if your Operation needs to be machined on the Inside.
Tool Inside - Specify the character that represents if your Operation needs to be machined on the Inside.
Tool Outside - Specify the character that represents if your Operation needs to be machined on the Outside.
Tool Outside - Specify the character that represents if your Operation needs to be machined on the Outside.

Secondary Face - Identifies that the Operation is on the Secondary Face. Without this designation on an operation the assumption is the Operation is on the Primary Face. This allows you to define machining on both faces of the Part from one DXF drawing.

Secondary Face - Identifies that the Operation is on the Secondary Face. Without this designation on an operation the assumption is the Operation is on the Primary Face. This allows you to define machining on both faces of the Part from one DXF drawing.
Miscellaneous  - There are 3 options in the Miscellaneous Section.

Decimal Separator - Specify what character you use as a decimal separator. Typically it is either the letter p or an underscore _. 
 
 
 Part Face Up - Specify what character you use to indicate the Part is Face Up. By default it is assumed to be Back Up. 
 
 
 Use Thickness as Depth - Set this to True if your CAD geometry includes a true thickness representation.
Decimal Separator - Specify what character you use as a decimal separator. Typically it is either the letter p or an underscore _.

Part Face Up - Specify what character you use to indicate the Part is Face Up. By default it is assumed to be Back Up.
Part Face Up - Specify what character you use to indicate the Part is Face Up. By default it is assumed to be Back Up.
Use Thickness as Depth - Set this to True if your CAD geometry includes a true thickness representation.
Use Thickness as Depth - Set this to True if your CAD geometry includes a true thickness representation.
If there is a duplicate Layer name or Keyword a notification occurs next to the OK button and you will be prompted to fix the problem before exiting, copying or selecting another scheme.
Information.png
The Part Layer should (but is not required) contain a rectangle representing the extent of the part. The Outline Layer should hold the part shape.
Information.png
Layer Breakdown
image258.png
The LeftEnd.dxf Imported above includes five Layers. Let's break them down:
Default_Layers.png
Layer Names are case sensitive.
Information.png
Dadoes can be defined three different ways, as shown below, to be interpreted correctly by the S2M CENTER.
Single Line with No Width   The S2M CENTER will define the Dado to the Right of your drawn Line and the Width must be defined in the Layer Name.
image280.gif
Single Line with Width   The S2M CENTER will define the Dado from the Center of the Line out based on the Width of the line.
image281.gif
Rectangle Polyline   The S2M CENTER will define the on the inside of the rectangle based on the Offset defined in your layer name.
image282.gif
Edit DXF Layer Names
image964.gif
This utility allows you to edit the Layer name passed by the DXF. Simply type the new layer name(s) you wish to use in the corresponding New Layer Name field.
image259.png
Known Limitations
Although the DXF Import reads a DXF file there are some differences between an output DXF and Input DXF that should be noted.

One DXF file per part. It is common to have a Partition output both a front and back program. However since each DXF file is assigned to a part the DXF file should contain both the face and the back operations rather than having them split between two DXF files. 
 No mirrored parts. The DXF files input should not be mirrored. Currently the application will only rotate part 90 degrees or flip the part over if necessary. 
 Operation size is assumed to be the bounding box of the operation.

One DXF file per part. It is common to have a Partition output both a front and back program. However since each DXF file is assigned to a part the DXF file should contain both the face and the back operations rather than having them split between two DXF files.
No mirrored parts. The DXF files input should not be mirrored. Currently the application will only rotate part 90 degrees or flip the part over if necessary.
Operation size is assumed to be the bounding box of the operation.
For example, if you output the tool path for a dado as centerline, the geometry for the dado is smaller than the actual dado required since the operation will grow by the tool diameter.
image445.jpg

A DXF file can define quite an assortment of CAD entities that the S2M CENTER can not process. If the S2M CENTER can not process an entity it will be ignored and a warning will be issued. The following entities are supported by the S2M CENTER:
       
 Arc 
 Circle 
 Line 
 LWPOLYLINE 
 POLYLINE 
 SEQEND 
 VERTEX
